Virginia Murdoch
Be careful; his bowtie is really a camera.
Mar 24

Weekend Things, W11–17

Street art, breadbots, women’s bodies, journalism, knitting, Zelda, and a dash of Trumpenfreude.

My dear friends Matt and Sahr run Yelldesign, a design studio focused on short-form stop-motion animation. They do fantastic work, and they’re in justifiably high demand from agencies and brands all over the world. A couple of weeks back they teamed up with artist Kate Banazi (who’s represented by the also excellent Jacky Winter Group) to paint an abstract mural on their Fitzroy house, and of course they produced a timelapse video showing the process. So good. They’ve also just started a second season of Paper Meals, this time looking at Cocktails.

Peter Dutton thinks that the CEOs of Australian companies should stay out of discussions about “social issues” and focus on their business interests. If 20 CEOs had banded together to condemn same-sex marriage, rather than stepping up in support of the million or so workers (✋🏼) whose lives are adversely affected by all the bullshit politics surrounding this issue, Dutton’d be all for it. This guy, by the way, is in contention for future leadership of the Liberal (lololololol) Party. (As an aside, fuck “stick to their knitting”; I know people who could knit a better Prime Minister than the Liberal Party has produced in the last thirty years).

Ugh, the second season of The Crown will focus on Prince Phillip’s ‘complexity’. Why.

Jim Moran’s patrol car was waiting. Moran is from the South Bronx, from Williams Ave., and he was brought up on Tony Bennett records in the jukeboxes. When he became a cop in 1964, he was put on patrol guarding the Beatles at their hotel. Girls screamed and pushed and Moran laughed. Once, it was all fun.

Jimmy Breslin, who died this week, on the cops who took John Lennon to the hospital after he was shot (via @fahrenthold).

This is a very good, if tough to read, article by Miki Perkins about a teenage girl who was raped in Geelong last year, and the effect of that horrible event on the girl and her family. The trial was abandoned because the victim felt unable to continue, and the three brothers who were charged with the crime therefore won’t face conviction.

“Mary’s entrepreneurial spirit — taking ride requests while she was in labor! — is an “exciting” example of how seamless and flexible app-based employment can be. Look at that hustle! You can make a quick buck with Lyft anytime, even when your cervix is dilating.”

Jia Tolentino on the ‘gig economy’ in the New Yorker.

I haven’t spent an enormous amount of time on Breath of the Wild yet — I’m only just leaving the Great Plateau — but it’s been immensely enjoyable so far. It’s just such a wonderful combination of nostalgia and new-ness. I’ve died about 40 times already, sometimes repeatedly attempting to defeat the same enemies, but somehow I’ve always cracked the puzzle moments before I would have otherwise given up in despair.

Some things I believed when I was young: Cosmopolitan magazine and its ilk are unequivocally bad for women, and the Pill is unequivocally good. Anyway, here’s Cosmo on Ivanka Trump, getting it pretty right. I guess I’m still forming my thoughts about the Pill, but I’ve had a few conversations with women this week about it, somewhat coincidentally, and not all of them have been positive. Which is not to say that you should stop taking it if it works for you, or that any of these fuckers should get to make decisions about it, or that these 52% of men should ever get any action ever again.

My pal Andy Taylor has made a marvellous bread proofing apparatus called Breadbot — it measures the temperature of your proofing box (or the inside of your oven) and adjusts it if it falls below a certain point, logging the status constantly. Breadnerds are the best nerds.

I have never seen a meme explosion quite like the one arising from Trump pretending to drive a truck. But this contribution is my favourite.

“To be honest, the biggest losers today are Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer,” Trump said of the House minority leader and the Senate minority leader. “Because now they own the disaster known as Obamacare.”

LOL. (Republicans failed to get their ACA repeal bill off the ground, and now it seems like they’ll walk away from their horribly misguided, unpopular, dangerous attempt, at least for this Congress.)
